docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
Get up and running with Zen Browser Bridge in just 5 minutes! This hands-on tutorial will walk you through the basics and show you the power of browser automation from the command line.

Prerequisites

Make sure you've completed the Installation guide before starting this tutorial.

docs.title: Quick Start Workflow
docs.text:
Here's what we'll cover in this tutorial:

graph LR
    A[Execute JavaScript] --> B[Use REPL]
    B --> C[Extract Data]
    C --> D[Automate Tasks]
    D --> E[Advanced Features]

    style A fill:#e1f5ff
    style B fill:#fff4e1
    style C fill:#ffe1f5
    style D fill:#fff9e6
    style E fill:#e1ffe1

docs.title: Step 1: Navigate to a Test Page
docs.text: Open your browser and navigate to https://example.com. Keep this tab active.

docs.title: Step 2: Execute JavaScript
docs.text:
Run your first command to get the page title:

zen eval "document.title"

Expected output:

Example Domain

Congratulations! You just executed JavaScript in your browser from the terminal.

docs.title: Step 3: Try More Expressions
docs.text:
# Get the current URL
zen eval "location.href"
# => https://example.com/

# Count paragraphs on the page
zen eval "document.querySelectorAll('p').length"
# => 2

# Get all link URLs
zen eval "Array.from(document.links).map(a => a.href)"
# => ["https://www.iana.org/domains/example"]

Quick Tip

The zen eval command evaluates JavaScript expressions. For more complex code, use zen exec with a file.

docs.title: Interactive REPL Session
docs.text:
The REPL (Read-Eval-Print Loop) lets you experiment with JavaScript interactively:

zen repl

Try these commands in the REPL:

// Get the page title
zen> document.title
"Example Domain"

// Query the DOM
zen> document.querySelectorAll('h1')[0].textContent
"Example Domain"

// Create an array of links
zen> Array.from(document.links).map(a => ({text: a.textContent, href: a.href}))
[{text: "More information...", href: "https://www.iana.org/domains/example"}]

// Exit the REPL
zen> exit
Goodbye!

REPL Power

The REPL is perfect for exploring APIs, debugging, and prototyping JavaScript code before adding it to scripts.

docs.title: Execute JavaScript from Files

Create a file extract-titles.js:

    level: h.tagName,
    text: h.textContent.trim(),
    id: h.id
  }));

headings;  // Return value

zen exec extract-titles.js --format json

Or use the shorthand:

zen exec extract-titles.js --format json
# Same as:
zen eval --file extract-titles.js --format json

Try these exercises to build your skills:

Challenge 1: Link Analysis

Navigate to your favorite news site and:

}" --format json > wikipedia.json

docs.title: Updating Zen Bridge
docs.text: Keep Zen Bridge up to date to get the latest features, bug fixes, and improvements.

docs.title: Updating the CLI
docs.text: The Zen Bridge CLI is installed via pip and can be updated with a single command.

docs.title: Check Current Version
docs.text: zen --version

docs.title: Update to Latest Version
docs.text:
pip install --upgrade zen-bridge

Or with pipx:

pipx upgrade zen-bridge

docs.title: Verify Update
docs.text:
zen --version
# Should show the new version

zen server restart
# Restart the server to use the new version

docs.title: Updating the Userscript
docs.text: The userscript runs in your browser and needs to be updated separately from the CLI.

docs.title: Automatic Updates (Recommended)
docs.text:
Since version 3.5, the userscript supports automatic updates:

  1. Tampermonkey/Violentmonkey will check for updates periodically (usually daily)
  2. You'll be prompted when an update is available
  3. Click "Update" to install the new version

To check manually:

  1. Open Tampermonkey/Violentmonkey dashboard
  2. Find "Zen Browser Bridge (WebSocket)"
  3. Click the "Check for updates" button
  4. Install if an update is available

docs.title: Manual Update
docs.text:
If you have version 3.4 or earlier (without auto-update):

  1. Open Tampermonkey/Violentmonkey dashboard
  2. Delete the old "Zen Browser Bridge" script
  3. Visit the raw userscript file: 
    https://raw.githubusercontent.com/roelvangils/zen-bridge/main/userscript_ws.js
  4. Tampermonkey/Violentmonkey will prompt to install the new version
  5. Click "Install"
  6. Reload any open tabs to activate the new version

docs.title: Verify Userscript Version
docs.text:
Open the browser console (F12) and check:

window.__ZEN_BRIDGE_VERSION__
// Should show "3.5" or higher

Or look for the version in the console on page load:

[Zen Bridge] Connected via WebSocket

docs.text:
Issue: Auto-update not working

You may have version 3.4 or earlier without auto-update support. Use the manual update method above.

Issue: Two versions installed

  1. Open Tampermonkey/Violentmonkey dashboard
  2. Look for duplicate "Zen Browser Bridge" entries
  3. Delete the older version (check version number in script header)
  4. Keep only the latest version

Issue: "Script already installed" error

#!/bin/bash

retry_command() {
  local max_attempts=3
  local attempt=1
  local delay=2

  while [ $attempt -le $max_attempts ]; do
    echo "Attempt $attempt/$max_attempts..."

    if "$@"; then
      return 0
    fi

    if [ $attempt -lt $max_attempts ]; then
      echo "Failed. Retrying in ${delay}s..."
      sleep $delay
      delay=$((delay * 2))
    fi

    attempt=$((attempt + 1))
  done

  echo "All attempts failed" >&2
  return 1
}

#!/bin/bash

cache_dir="$HOME/.zen-cache"
cache_ttl=300  # 5 minutes

mkdir -p "$cache_dir"

get_cached_or_fetch() {
  local key="$1"
  local command="$2"
  local cache_file="$cache_dir/$(echo "$key" | md5sum | cut -d' ' -f1)"

  # Check cache
  if [ -f "$cache_file" ]; then
    age=$(($(date +%s) - $(stat -c %Y "$cache_file")))
    if [ $age -lt $cache_ttl ]; then
      cat "$cache_file"
      return 0
    fi
  fi

  # Fetch and cache
  result=$(eval "$command")
  echo "$result" > "$cache_file"
  echo "$result"
}

docs.text: Before you can use any commands, the bridge server must be running.

docs.title: Starting the Server
docs.text:
Background Mode (Recommended)Foreground ModeCustom Port 
zen server start --daemon

Starts the server in the background. You can close your terminal and the server keeps running.

zen server start

Starts the server in foreground mode. Useful for debugging. Press Ctrl+C to stop.

zen server start --port 9000 --daemon

Start on a different port (default is 8765).

Auto-start on Login

On macOS/Linux, you can create a launch agent or systemd service to start the server automatically when you log in.

docs.title: Stopping the Server

zen server stop

Only works if the server is running in foreground mode. For daemon mode, use:

pkill -f "zen server"

Daemon Mode Limitation

There's no built-in daemon stop command yet. Use pkill as shown above.

docs.title: Executing JavaScript Code
docs.text: The zen eval command is your primary way to execute JavaScript in the browser.

docs.title: Basic Syntax
docs.text: zen eval "javascript_code_here"

docs.title: Simple Expressions
docs.text:
Get quick information from the page:

# Page title
zen eval "document.title"
# Output: Example Domain

# Page URL
zen eval "location.href"
# Output: https://example.com/

# Number of links
zen eval "document.links.length"
# Output: 15

# Get domain
zen eval "location.hostname"
# Output: example.com

docs.title: Complex Expressions
docs.text:
Use arrays, objects, and methods:

# Extract all links
zen eval "Array.from(document.links).map(a => a.href)"

# Get multiple properties
zen eval "({url: location.href, title: document.title, links: document.links.length})"

# Filter elements
zen eval "Array.from(document.querySelectorAll('a')).filter(a => a.hostname !== location.hostname).map(a => a.href)"

docs.title: Multi-line Code
docs.text:
For complex logic, use proper JavaScript syntax:

zen eval "
  const links = Array.from(document.querySelectorAll('a'));
  const internal = links.filter(a => a.hostname === location.hostname);
  const external = links.filter(a => a.hostname !== location.hostname);
  return {
    total: links.length,
    internal: internal.length,
    external: external.length
  };
"

Semicolons Matter

When using multiple statements, separate them with semicolons. The last expression is automatically returned.

docs.title: Using stdin
docs.text:

# From a file
cat script.js | zen eval

# From echo
echo "document.title" | zen eval

# From heredoc
zen eval <<'EOF'
const images = document.querySelectorAll('img');
return Array.from(images).map(img => ({
  src: img.src,
  alt: img.alt,
  width: img.naturalWidth,
  height: img.naturalHeight
}));
EOF

docs.title: Control Mode
docs.text: Master keyboard-only navigation with Zen Bridge Control Mode. Navigate pages entirely from your terminal using Tab, Enter, and Arrow keys.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
zen control provides keyboard-only navigation for accessibility testing and hands-free browsing. It's perfect for:

  • Accessibility testing - Verify keyboard navigation
  • Hands-free browsing - Navigate without a mouse
  • Screen reader compatibility - Test with keyboard + voice
  • Focus management testing - Verify focus indicators
  • Navigation persistence - Auto-refocus after page loads

docs.title: Starting Control Mode
docs.text:
zen control

What happens:

  1. Terminal enters raw mode (captures all keyboard input)
  2. Browser receives keyboard events in real-time
  3. Focus indicators appear on interactive elements
  4. Terminal displays announcements and feedback
  5. Mode persists across page navigations

To exit: Press Ctrl+D or q

docs.title: Basic Controls
docs.text: Key Action Tab Navigate forward through focusable elements Shift+Tab Navigate backward Enter Activate focused element (click/submit) Space Activate focused element Arrow Keys Navigate directionally Escape Return focus to body q Quit control mode Ctrl+D Quit control mode

docs.title: How It Works
docs.text:
Control mode captures your keystrokes and sends them to the browser:

  1. You press Tab in terminal
  2. Zen sends Tab to browser
  3. Browser shifts focus to next element
  4. Element is highlighted with blue outline
  5. Terminal announces element name and role

docs.title: Visual Feedback
docs.text: Focused elements get a blue outline (outline: 2px solid blue) so you can see what's focused.

docs.title: Terminal Announcements

Focus: Email Input (input)
Focus: Privacy Policy (link)

# Press Enter → Page loads
# → Focus automatically returns to the link
# Continue tabbing from there

This is unique to Zen Bridge - the focus persists even after navigation!

docs.title: Data Extraction
docs.text: Master data extraction with Zen Bridge. Learn how to extract links, generate page outlines, get selected text, download files, and extract structured data from web pages.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Zen Bridge provides specialized commands for data extraction:

  • zen links - Extract and analyze links
  • zen outline - Display page heading structure
  • zen selected - Get selected text
  • zen download - Find and download files
  • zen info - Get page metadata

docs.title: Extracting Links
docs.text: The zen links command extracts all links from a page with powerful filtering options.

docs.title: Basic Usage
docs.text:
zen links

Output: 

→ Home Page
  https://example.com/

↗ External Resource
  https://other-site.com/page

Total: 15 links (8 internal, 7 external)

Shows: - Link text (anchor text) - URL - Internal (→) vs External (↗) indicators - Summary count

docs.title: Filter to Internal Links
docs.text:
zen links --only-internal

Shows only links to the same domain.

docs.title: Filter to External Links
docs.text:
zen links --only-external

Shows only links to other domains.

docs.title: URLs Only
docs.text:
zen links --only-urls

Outputs just URLs (one per line), perfect for piping:

https://example.com/page1
https://example.com/page2
https://external.com/resource

docs.title: Alphabetical Sorting
docs.text:
zen links --alphabetically

Sorts links alphabetically by URL.

docs.title: Link Enrichment
docs.text:
Get detailed metadata for external links:

zen links --enrich-external

Fetches: - HTTP status code - MIME type (content-type) - File size - Page title - Language

Example output: 

↗ Documentation
  https://docs.example.com/
  Status: 200 OK | Type: text/html | Size: 42KB | Lang: en
  Title: Example Docs - Getting Started

docs.title: JSON Output
docs.text:
zen links --json

Outputs structured JSON for scripting:

{
  "links": [
    {
      "text": "Home Page",
      "url": "https://example.com/",
      "internal": true
    },
    {
      "text": "External Resource",
      "url": "https://other-site.com/page",
      "internal": false,
      "status": 200,
      "contentType": "text/html",
      "size": 42170,
      "title": "Resource Title",
      "language": "en"
    }
  ],
  "summary": {
    "total": 15,
    "internal": 8,
    "external": 7
  }
}

docs.title: Combined Filters
docs.text:
# External URLs only, alphabetically sorted
zen links --only-external --only-urls --alphabetically

# Internal links as JSON
zen links --only-internal --json

# External links with enrichment
zen links --only-external --enrich-external

docs.title: Practical Uses
docs.text:
Export links for analysis: 

zen links --only-external --only-urls > external-links.txt

Count total links: 

zen links --only-urls | wc -l

Find PDF links: 

zen links --only-urls | grep "\.pdf$"

Check broken links: 

zen links --only-urls | xargs -I {} curl -s -o /dev/null -w "%{http_code} {}\n" {}

Extract and process with jq: 

zen links --json | jq '.links[] | select(.internal == false) | .url'

docs.title: Advanced Extraction with eval
docs.text: For custom extraction needs, use zen eval:

docs.title: Extract Table Data
docs.text:
zen eval "
  const table = document.querySelector('table');
  const headers = Array.from(table.querySelectorAll('th')).map(th => th.textContent.trim());
  const rows = Array.from(table.querySelectorAll('tbody tr')).map(tr =>
    Array.from(tr.cells).map(cell => cell.textContent.trim())
  );
  return {headers, rows};
" --format json > table.json

docs.title: Extract Product Data
docs.text:
zen eval "
  Array.from(document.querySelectorAll('.product')).map(product => ({
    name: product.querySelector('.product-name').textContent.trim(),
    price: product.querySelector('.product-price').textContent.trim(),
    rating: product.querySelector('.rating')?.textContent,
    image: product.querySelector('img')?.src,
    available: !product.classList.contains('out-of-stock')
  }))
" --format json > products.json

docs.title: Extract Article Content
docs.text:
zen eval "
  ({
    title: document.querySelector('h1')?.textContent,
    author: document.querySelector('.author')?.textContent,
    date: document.querySelector('time')?.getAttribute('datetime'),
    content: document.querySelector('article')?.textContent.trim(),
    tags: Array.from(document.querySelectorAll('.tag')).map(t => t.textContent.trim())
  })
" --format json > article.json

docs.title: Extract All Images
docs.text:
zen eval "
  Array.from(document.images).map(img => ({
    src: img.src,
    alt: img.alt,
    width: img.naturalWidth,
    height: img.naturalHeight,
    title: img.title,
    loading: img.loading
  }))
" --format json > images.json

docs.title: Extract Meta Tags
docs.text:
zen eval "
  const meta = {};
  document.querySelectorAll('meta').forEach(tag => {
    const name = tag.name || tag.property;
    if (name) meta[name] = tag.content;
  });
  return meta;
" --format json > meta.json

docs.title: Extract Forms
docs.text:
zen eval "
  Array.from(document.forms).map(form => ({
    action: form.action,
    method: form.method,
    id: form.id,
    fields: Array.from(form.elements)
      .filter(el => el.name)
      .map(el => ({
        name: el.name,
        type: el.type,
        required: el.required,
        placeholder: el.placeholder
      }))
  }))
" --format json > forms.json

docs.title: Extract Structured Data (JSON-LD)
docs.text:
zen eval "
  Array.from(document.querySelectorAll('script[type=\"application/ld+json\"]'))
    .map(script => JSON.parse(script.textContent))
" --format json > structured-data.json

docs.title: Text Normalization
docs.text:
zen eval "
  const text = document.querySelector('.content').textContent;
  return text
    .trim()
    .replace(/\s+/g, ' ')      // Multiple spaces to single
    .replace(/\n+/g, '\n');     // Multiple newlines to single
" --format raw

docs.title: HTML Stripping
docs.text:
zen eval "
  const html = document.querySelector('.content').innerHTML;
  const temp = document.createElement('div');
  temp.innerHTML = html;
  return temp.textContent.trim();
" --format raw

docs.title: Data Validation
docs.text:
zen eval "
  Array.from(document.querySelectorAll('.item'))
    .map(item => ({
      title: item.querySelector('.title')?.textContent.trim(),
      link: item.querySelector('a')?.href
    }))
    .filter(item => item.title && item.link);  // Remove incomplete
" --format json

docs.title: URL Normalization
docs.text:
zen eval "
  Array.from(document.links).map(a => {
    try {
      return new URL(a.href).href;  // Normalize URL
    } catch {
      return null;
    }
  }).filter(Boolean);
" --format json

docs.title: Scrape Multiple Pages
docs.text:
#!/bin/bash
# Extract data from multiple pages

URLS=(
  "https://example.com/page1"
  "https://example.com/page2"
  "https://example.com/page3"
)

for url in "${URLS[@]}"; do
  echo "Extracting: $url"
  zen open "$url" --wait
  zen eval "({title: document.title, links: document.links.length})" --format json >> data.jsonl
done

docs.title: Export All Page Data
docs.text:
#!/bin/bash
# Complete page export

PAGE_URL=$(zen eval "location.href" --format raw)
PAGE_TITLE=$(zen eval "document.title" --format raw)

mkdir -p "export/${PAGE_TITLE}"

# Links
zen links --json > "export/${PAGE_TITLE}/links.json"

# Outline
zen outline > "export/${PAGE_TITLE}/outline.txt"

# Metadata
zen info --json > "export/${PAGE_TITLE}/info.json"

# Screenshots
zen screenshot --selector "body" --output "export/${PAGE_TITLE}/screenshot.png"

echo "Exported: ${PAGE_TITLE}"

docs.title: 1. Limit Results
docs.text:
zen eval "
  Array.from(document.querySelectorAll('.item'))
    .slice(0, 100)  // First 100 only
    .map(item => item.textContent)
" --format json

docs.title: 2. Extract Only What You Need
docs.text:
zen eval "
  // Good - extract only titles
  Array.from(document.querySelectorAll('.item'))
    .map(item => item.querySelector('.title').textContent)
"

docs.title: 3. Use Efficient Selectors
docs.text:
# Good - specific selector
zen eval "document.querySelectorAll('.product .title')"

# Avoid - overly broad
zen eval "document.querySelectorAll('*').filter(...)"

docs.title: 4. Batch DOM Queries
docs.text:
zen eval "
  const container = document.querySelector('.container');
  const items = container.querySelectorAll('.item');  // Query once
  return Array.from(items).map(item => ({
    title: item.querySelector('.title').textContent,
    link: item.querySelector('a').href
  }));
"

docs.title: Element Interaction
docs.text: Master element interaction in Zen Bridge. Learn how to click, inspect, highlight, wait for elements, send keyboard input, and take screenshots - all from your terminal.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Zen Bridge provides specialized commands for interacting with page elements:

  • zen click - Click elements
  • zen double-click / zen right-click - Double-click and right-click
  • zen wait - Wait for elements to appear/disappear
  • zen send - Type text into elements
  • zen inspect / zen inspected - Inspect elements
  • zen highlight - Highlight elements visually
  • zen screenshot - Screenshot elements

docs.title: Basic Click
docs.text:
zen click "button#submit"

Clicks the first element matching the selector.

docs.title: Click Examples
docs.text:
# Click button by ID
zen click "#submit-btn"

# Click link by class
zen click ".nav-link"

# Click by complex selector
zen click "nav > ul > li:first-child > a"

# Click by attribute
zen click "[data-action='delete']"

# Click by text content (using eval)
zen eval "Array.from(document.querySelectorAll('button')).find(b => b.textContent.includes('Submit')).click()"

docs.title: Using Inspected Element
docs.text:
You can click the currently inspected element (from DevTools):

# In DevTools, select an element ($0)
# In browser console: zenStore($0)

# Then click it
zen click
# or explicitly
zen click "$0"

docs.title: Double Click
docs.text:
Double-click elements for actions that require it:

zen double-click "div.editable"
zen double-click ".file-item"

docs.title: Right Click (Context Menu)
docs.text:
Trigger context menus:

zen right-click "a.download-link"
zen right-click ".file-item"

Click Types

  • zen click - Single left click
  • zen double-click - Double left click
  • zen right-click - Right click (context menu)

zen wait ".success-message" --visible

Wait for loading to finish:

zen click ".load-more"

# Wait for spinner to disappear

Timeout Default

Default timeout is 30 seconds. Adjust with --timeout flag.

zen eval "
  async function waitForElement(selector, timeout = 30000) {
    const start = Date.now();
    while (Date.now() - start < timeout) {
      const element = document.querySelector(selector);
      if (element) return element;
      await new Promise(resolve => setTimeout(resolve, 100));
    }
    throw new Error('Timeout');
  }

  const element = await waitForElement('.dynamic-content');
  return element.textContent;
"

docs.title: JavaScript Execution
docs.text: Master JavaScript execution in Zen Bridge. Learn inline code execution, file execution, stdin piping, timeout handling, error handling, output formatting, and advanced patterns.

docs.title: Execution Methods
docs.text: Zen Bridge offers three ways to execute JavaScript code in your browser.

docs.title: 1. Inline Code Execution
docs.text:
Execute code directly from the command line:

zen eval "document.title"

Best for: - Quick one-liners - Testing expressions - Shell scripts with short code snippets

docs.title: 2. File Execution
docs.text:
Execute code from JavaScript files:

zen eval --file script.js
# or
zen exec script.js

Best for: - Complex scripts - Reusable code - Version-controlled automation

docs.title: 3. stdin Piping
docs.text:
Pipe code from stdin:

cat script.js | zen eval
echo "document.title" | zen eval

Best for: - Generated code - Dynamic scripts - Shell pipelines

docs.title: Simple Expressions
docs.text:
# Get page title
zen eval "document.title"

# Get URL
zen eval "window.location.href"

# Count elements
zen eval "document.querySelectorAll('a').length"

# Check if element exists
zen eval "document.querySelector('.modal') !== null"

docs.title: Complex Expressions
docs.text:
# Array operations
zen eval "Array.from(document.links).map(a => a.href)"

# Object literals (wrap in parentheses)
zen eval "({title: document.title, url: location.href})"

# Filter and map
zen eval "Array.from(document.querySelectorAll('img')).filter(img => img.alt).map(img => img.src)"

# Reduce
zen eval "Array.from(document.links).reduce((acc, link) => acc + link.textContent.length, 0)"

docs.title: Multi-line Code
docs.text:
Use newlines and proper JavaScript syntax:

zen eval "
  const products = document.querySelectorAll('.product');
  const data = Array.from(products).map(p => ({
    name: p.querySelector('.name').textContent,
    price: p.querySelector('.price').textContent
  }));
  return data;
"

Multi-line Tips

  • Separate statements with semicolons
  • Use return for the final value
  • Proper indentation makes code readable

docs.title: Handling Quotes
docs.text:
Shell quoting can be tricky. Here are the rules:

# Double quotes - escape inner double quotes
zen eval "document.querySelector(\"h1\").textContent"

# Single quotes in double quotes - no escaping needed
zen eval "document.querySelector('h1').textContent"

# Backticks for template literals - use single quotes outside
zen eval 'document.querySelector("h1").textContent = `Hello ${name}`'

# Heredoc for complex quoting
zen eval <<'EOF'
const selector = 'div[data-value="complex"]';
const element = document.querySelector(selector);
return element?.textContent;
EOF

docs.title: Basic File Execution
docs.text:
script.js: 

// Extract all links
const links = Array.from(document.querySelectorAll('a'));
return links.map(link => ({
  text: link.textContent.trim(),
  href: link.href,
  external: link.hostname !== location.hostname
}));

Execute: 

zen exec script.js
# or
zen eval --file script.js

docs.title: File with Modules
docs.text:
Modern JavaScript syntax is supported:

extract-data.js: 

// Extract product data with validation
const products = Array.from(document.querySelectorAll('.product'));

function extractProduct(element) {
  const name = element.querySelector('.product-name')?.textContent?.trim();
  const price = element.querySelector('.product-price')?.textContent?.trim();
  const image = element.querySelector('.product-image')?.src;

  // Validate required fields
  if (!name || !price) return null;

  return { name, price, image };
}

const data = products.map(extractProduct).filter(Boolean);

return {
  count: data.length,
  products: data,
  extracted: new Date().toISOString()
};

2. Write your script:

return prices.map(p => ({

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Welcome to Zen Bridge - a powerful CLI tool that lets you control your browser from the command line. Execute JavaScript, automate tasks, extract data, and interact with web pages without leaving your terminal.

docs.title: What is Zen Bridge?
docs.text:
Zen Bridge is a command-line interface that connects your terminal to your web browser through a WebSocket-based architecture. It allows you to:

  • Execute JavaScript code in your active browser tab
  • Interact with page elements (click, inspect, highlight, wait)
  • Extract data (links, images, tables, metadata)
  • Automate form filling and navigation
  • Debug and test web applications
  • Monitor browser activity in real-time
  • Control your browser entirely from your keyboard

Think of it as a bridge between your terminal and your browser - hence the name.

docs.title: 1. CLI Tool (Your Terminal)
docs.text:
When you run commands like zen eval "document.title", the CLI tool:

  • Parses your command and options
  • Formats the JavaScript code
  • Sends an HTTP request to the local server
  • Waits for the response
  • Displays the result

docs.title: 2. Bridge Server (Background Process)
docs.text:
The server acts as a message broker:

  • Listens for HTTP requests from the CLI (port 8765)
  • Maintains WebSocket connections with browser tabs (port 8766)
  • Routes commands to the active browser tab
  • Returns results back to the CLI
  • Runs in the background as a daemon

Start the server with: 

zen server start --daemon

docs.title: 3. Browser Userscript (In Your Browser)
docs.text:
A lightweight userscript runs in your browser:

  • Establishes a WebSocket connection to the server
  • Receives JavaScript code from the server
  • Executes the code in the page context
  • Sends results back to the server
  • Works across page navigations

The userscript must be installed in a userscript manager like Violentmonkey or Tampermonkey.

docs.title: Why WebSockets?
docs.text:
Traditional HTTP polling would be slow and inefficient. WebSockets provide:

  • Instant communication - No polling delays
  • Bi-directional - Server can push to browser, browser can push to server
  • Persistent connection - One connection serves multiple commands
  • Low overhead - Minimal latency compared to HTTP requests

docs.title: Message Flow Example
docs.text:
When you run zen eval "document.title":

  1. CLI → Server (HTTP) 

    POST http://127.0.0.1:8765/execute
{
  "code": "document.title",
  "timeout": 10
}

  2. Server → Browser (WebSocket) 

    {
  "type": "execute",
  "code": "document.title",
  "id": "req-123"
}

  3. Browser executes code and responds (WebSocket) 

    {
  "type": "response",
  "id": "req-123",
  "result": "Example Domain",
  "ok": true
}

  4. Server → CLI (HTTP Response) 

    {
  "ok": true,
  "result": "Example Domain"
}

  5. CLI displays output 

    Example Domain

docs.title: Security Considerations
docs.text:
The WebSocket connection is local only:

  • Server binds to 127.0.0.1 (localhost)
  • Not accessible from external networks
  • No authentication needed (local-only access)
  • Userscript only connects to localhost

This means Zen Bridge can only control browsers on your own machine.

docs.title: When to Use Zen Bridge
docs.text: Zen Bridge is ideal for:

docs.title: Web Development & Debugging
docs.text:
• Inspect application state (window.myApp, Redux stores)
  • Test JavaScript functions interactively
  • Debug DOM manipulations
  • Monitor performance metrics
  • Inject jQuery or other libraries for testing

docs.title: Web Scraping & Data Extraction

docs.title: Architecture Benefits
docs.text:
Zen Bridge follows a hexagonal architecture with clear separation of concerns:

  • Domain Layer - Pure business logic with Pydantic models
  • Adapter Layer - I/O operations (filesystem, WebSocket)
  • Service Layer - Application services and orchestration

This design ensures:

  • High testability (97%+ coverage on services)
  • Clear dependencies (no circular imports)
  • Easy extensibility (add new commands/services)
  • Maintainable codebase

docs.title: Troubleshooting CSP Issues
docs.text: This guide helps you understand and troubleshoot Content Security Policy (CSP) issues with Zen Bridge.

docs.title: What is CSP?
docs.text:
Content Security Policy (CSP) is a security feature that websites use to control what resources (scripts, styles, connections) can be loaded and executed on their pages.

CSP is implemented through HTTP headers or <meta> tags and acts as a protective barrier against: - Cross-site scripting (XSS) attacks - Data injection attacks - Unauthorized script execution - Unwanted network connections

docs.title: Why Zen Bridge May Not Work
docs.text: Zen Bridge requires two things that CSP can block:

docs.title: 1. JavaScript Execution
docs.text: When you run commands like zen eval "document.title", Zen injects JavaScript into the page. Strict CSP policies may block this.

docs.title: 2. WebSocket Connection
docs.text: The userscript connects to ws://localhost:8766 to communicate with the Zen CLI. CSP's connect-src directive can block connections to localhost.

docs.title: In Browser Console
docs.text:
Open your browser's DevTools (F12) and look for errors like:

Refused to connect to 'ws://localhost:8766' because it violates the
following Content Security Policy directive: "connect-src 'self'"

docs.title: Zen Bridge Warning
docs.text:
Starting with version 3.5, Zen Bridge automatically detects CSP and shows a warning:

⚠️ Zen Bridge: CSP Detected

This website has Content Security Policy (CSP) restrictions that block Zen Bridge.

What this means:
• WebSocket connections to localhost are blocked
• Zen commands will not work on this page

Why this happens:
• High-security sites (GitHub, banking, government) use CSP
• CSP prevents unauthorized scripts and connections
• This is a security feature, not a bug

docs.title: Manual Check
docs.text:
Check if a site has CSP using curl:

curl -I https://example.com | grep -i content-security

Example output: 

Content-Security-Policy: default-src 'self'; connect-src 'self' https://api.example.com

This policy blocks WebSocket connections to localhost.

docs.title: High-Security Sites (Usually Blocked)
docs.text:
Sites with strict CSP that typically block Zen Bridge:

  • Code Hosting: GitHub, GitLab, Bitbucket
  • Google Services: Gmail, Drive, Docs, Cloud Console
  • Financial: Banking websites, payment processors
  • Government: Government portals, public services
  • Enterprise: Corporate intranals, cloud platforms (AWS, Azure)
  • Security-Focused: Password managers, VPN services

docs.title: Sites That Usually Work
docs.text:
• News websites (most)
  • Blogs and personal sites
  • Documentation sites
  • E-commerce (many)
  • Social media (some)
  • Local development servers

docs.title: ✅ Test on Different Sites
docs.text:
The simplest solution is to use Zen Bridge on sites without strict CSP:

# Works on most sites
zen eval "document.title"

# Try different domains
zen eval "window.location.href"

docs.title: ✅ Verify Server is Running
docs.text:
Sometimes the issue isn't CSP:

# Check if server is running
zen server status

# Restart if needed
zen server restart

docs.title: ✅ Check Browser Console
docs.text:
Always check the browser console for specific error messages:

  1. Open DevTools (F12)
  2. Go to Console tab
  3. Look for Zen Bridge messages or CSP violations
  4. Share error messages when reporting issues

docs.title: ❌ What Won't Work
docs.text:
These approaches do not work and are not recommended:

  1. Disabling CSP in browser - Removes all security, very dangerous
  2. Modifying HTTP headers - Requires browser extension with elevated privileges
  3. Proxying through another domain - CSP still blocks injected scripts

docs.title: Future Solutions
docs.text: We're exploring ways to make Zen Bridge work with CSP:

docs.title: Browser Extension (Future)
docs.text:
A full browser extension (not just a userscript) could: - Use chrome.tabs.executeScript() API with CSP bypass - Maintain WebSocket connections with elevated privileges - Require installation from Chrome/Firefox store

Trade-offs: - More installation steps - Store review process - More restrictive permissions needed

docs.title: CSP-Compatible Mode (Future)
docs.text:
A limited mode that works within CSP constraints: - Read-only operations - No arbitrary script execution - Limited to predefined commands

Trade-offs: - Reduced functionality - No custom JavaScript evaluation - Limited use cases

docs.title: Reporting CSP Issues
docs.text:
If you encounter CSP issues on sites where you'd expect Zen to work:

  1. Check the browser console for specific CSP errors
  2. Note the website URL and any error messages
  3. Test on a different site to verify Zen works elsewhere
  4. Report the issue at: https://github.com/roelvangils/zen-bridge/issues

Include: - Website URL (if public) - CSP policy (from curl or browser) - Error messages from console - Zen Bridge version (zen --version)

docs.title: CSP Directives That Affect Zen
docs.text: Directive Impact Example Blocking Policy connect-src Blocks WebSocket connect-src 'self' script-src Blocks injected scripts script-src 'self' default-src Fallback for other directives default-src 'none'

docs.title: What Zen Bridge Needs
docs.text:
For Zen Bridge to work, the CSP must allow:

Content-Security-Policy:
  connect-src 'self' ws://localhost:8766 ws://127.0.0.1:8766;
  script-src 'self' 'unsafe-eval';

Most high-security sites will never allow this, by design.

docs.title: Detection Methods
docs.text:
Zen Bridge uses multiple methods to detect CSP:

  1. Meta tag detection: Checks for <meta http-equiv="Content-Security-Policy">
  2. Connection failure patterns: Multiple failed WebSocket attempts
  3. Error message analysis: Catches CSP-related error messages

docs.title: GitHub (Strict CSP)
docs.text:
$ curl -I https://github.com | grep -i content-security
Content-Security-Policy: default-src 'none'; connect-src 'self' *.github.com

Result: ❌ Zen Bridge blocked (localhost not in connect-src)

docs.title: Personal Blog (No CSP)
docs.text:
$ curl -I https://example-blog.com | grep -i content-security
# No CSP header

Result: ✅ Zen Bridge works

docs.title: E-commerce Site (Moderate CSP)
docs.text:
$ curl -I https://shop.example.com | grep -i content-security
Content-Security-Policy: default-src 'self'; connect-src 'self' https:

Result: ❌ Zen Bridge blocked (https: only, no ws://)

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text:
1. Test before relying on Zen - Verify it works on your target sites
  2. Use for development - Works great on localhost and dev environments
  3. Report unexpected blocks - Help us improve CSP detection
  4. Stay informed - Watch for updates on CSP compatibility

docs.title: Why don't you just bypass CSP?
docs.text:
CSP is a critical security feature. Bypassing it would: - Require dangerous browser modifications - Compromise site security - Violate browser security policies - Put users at risk

Zen Bridge respects web security standards.

docs.title: Will this ever be fixed?
docs.text:
"Fixed" implies CSP is a bug - it's not. CSP is working as designed.

We're exploring alternatives like browser extensions, but these require different installation and permission models.

docs.title: Can I whitelist localhost in CSP?
docs.text:
Only site owners can modify their CSP policy. If you control the website, you can add:

Content-Security-Policy: connect-src 'self' ws://localhost:8766

But this only works for your own sites.

docs.title: Does this affect all userscripts?
docs.text:
CSP affects any tool that: - Injects scripts into pages - Makes external connections - Executes dynamic code

This is a common limitation of browser automation tools on high-security sites.

docs.title: Summary
docs.text:
• CSP is a security feature, not a bug
  • High-security sites block Zen by design
  • Zen Bridge detects and warns about CSP (v3.5+)
  • Use Zen on sites without strict CSP
  • Report unexpected issues to help improve detection

For most use cases (development, testing, personal sites), Zen Bridge works great. For high-security production sites, CSP restrictions are intentional and appropriate.
